dc:description:
IL2RB deficiency was first reported as the cause of autosomal recessive immunodeficiency 63 with lymphoproliferation and autoimmune disease in 2019 (Fernadez et al., PMID: 31040184). Patients with this disorder have a susceptibility to herpesvirus infections as well as severe autoimmune and inflammatory disease in the form of autoimmune haemolytic anaemia, enteropathy, dermatitis, hypergammaglobulinemia, lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. 

Four variants (missense and nonsense) that have been reported in 5 probands in 2 publications (PMIDs: 31040184, 31040185) are included in this curation. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 5 additional family members. The heterozygous parents all appear unaffected. A further case is available as a poster abstract (https://doi.org/10.1136/flgastro-2021-bspghan.33) that was unable to be scored, however personal correspondence confirmed the patient shared the same variant (L77P) as reported in two of the scored probands (PMID: 31040185). 

The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function. Autosomal recessive immunodeficiency 63 with lymphoproliferation and autoimmune disease is caused by partial or complete biallelic loss of function of IL2RB resulting in impaired IL-2 and IL-15 signaling, immune dysregulation and autoimmunity. 

This gene-disease relationship is supported by animal models, expression studies, functional studies and rescue in animal and patient cells (PMIDs: 23352221, 1631559, 8026467, 10706676, 7770771, 31040185). IL2RB encodes the beta subunit of the IL-2 and IL-15 receptors, and is expressed on resting T cells, NK cells, monocytes and neutrophils. The expression and function of IL2RB is reviewed by Liao et al (2013). There are many studies examining the function and expression of IL2RB, and both IL-2 and IL-15 are important in lymphocyte development and regulation. Suzuki et al (1995) first described the Il2rb -/- mouse which displays some phenotypic similarities to that of humans with IL2RB deficiency including lethal autoimmune disease and lymphoproliferation. Further studies on this mouse demonstrated that either thymic IL2RB expression or adoptive transfer of T regulatory cells (CD4+CD25+) was sufficient to rescue the autoimmune immunophenotype (Malek et al., 2000). Finally, transduction of affected patient cells with IL-2RB partially restores deficient IL-2 signaling (Zhang et al., 2019). 
	
In summary, there is moderate evidence supporting the relationship between IL2RB and autosomal recessive immunodeficiency 63 with lymphoproliferation and autoimmune disease. This evidence has been reported in both research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time, though at the time of this curation, only 5 probands have been reported in two publications. This classification was approved by the ClinGen PIRD GCEP on the meeting date December 12, 2023 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description:
Consanguinuity
Functional evidence from patient cells only
Not found in gnomAD

Dramatically reduced IL-2Rb surface expression on lymphocytes
Both parents also have somewhat reduced IL-2Rb expression

Elevated IL-2 and IL-15 compared to age matched controls. 
Elevated baseline pSTAT5 levels in NK- and T-cells consistent with continuous IL-2Rb stimulation, but decreased signalling responses to increased concentration of IL-2 and IL-15 in vitro

Expansion of NK cells. Intact cytotoxicity via chromium release assay but decreased IFN-gamma production and CD107a mobilisation in CD56bright NK cells on expsoure to K562 or ADCC. Decreased CD57 expression

evidence.rdfs:label: Fernandez P1
evidence.detectionMethod:
Microarray demonstrating large regions of homozygosity
Whole exome sequencing identified multiple variants of which IL2RB was the most suspicious
Homozygosity performed by Sanger sequencing

evidence.dc:description: Variant scored despite being the same variant as A1 as few variants reported in the literature. Score reduced due to consanguinity. Unlikely to be related to family A

evidence.rdfs:label: B2
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing with confirmation of the variant by Sanger sequencing

evidence.rdfs:label: Zhang D

member.rdfs:label: D1
member.detectionMethod:
Whole exome sequencing
Confirmed with Sanger sequencing
member.phenotypeFreeText: Lymphocytic infiltration of the skin and various organs

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Lymphocytic infiltration of the skin and various organs

evidence.dc:description:
Consanguineous parents
Not found in any databases

Absent IL2RB expression in thymic tissue

Expression of this mutation in HEK293 results in no response to IL2 stimulation

Patient cells show IL2RB surface expression present but no response to IL-2 stimulation. 

HEK293 transfected with Ser40Leu show decreased affinity for IL-2 (comparable to negative control) by flow cytometry measurement of bound IL-2

Markedly decreased surface expression of IL2Rb on both patient lymphocytes and transfected HEK293T cells, but increased cytosolic lysates implying cytosolic sequestration due to misfolding.

Some phosphorylation of STAT5 in response to IL-2 in transfected HEK293T system, but absent STAT5 in response to IL-2 and IL-15 in patient cells. 

Elevated IL-2 and IL-15. Significantly reduced Tregs. Expansion of NK cells. 

Patient NK cells are poor producers of IFNy in response to IL-2 and IL-15. Absent CD57 on NK cells.

IL2RB knock out mouse demonstrates absent surface IL2RB expression as with severe IL2RB mutations seen in humans and reduced expression seen in hypomorphic IL2RB variants seen in humans. 

Many phenotypic features are in common such as the development of splenomegaly and autoimmunity, as well as early lethality.
evidence.rdfs:label: IL2RB knock out mouse

evidence.dc:description: Already reached max score for model + rescue

IL-2RB expression normalised in thymic tissue but expression remained low in the peripheral compartment (splenic tissue). 

Thymic IL-2RB expression did not rescue absent NK cell cytotoxicity. 

Transgenic mice had normal body weight, no development of autoantibodies, no splenomegaly, and normal immunoglobulin levels demonstrating that thymic expression of IL-2RB was sufficient to rescue autoimmune phenotype.

Further work (PMID: 12196288) demonstrated that these transgenic mice had a two-fold increase in CD4+CD25+ T-cells (Tregs) in their lymph nodes and thymus. Adoptive transfer for CD4+CD25+ T-cells into. IL-2RB -/- mice was able to prevent lethal autoimmunity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transgenic thymic expression of IL2RB in -/- mice

evidence.dc:description:
Transduced cells had high levels of surface IL-2RB expression. 

Transduced cells were able to phosphorylate STAT3 and STAT5 in response to IL-2. Did not restore to same level as a healthy control but significantly higher than non-transduced patient cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lentiviral rescue of IL2RB and STAT phosphorylation

evidence.dc:description: Strong evidence available for the function of IL2RB.

Co-expression of IL-2R beta and gamma chains in murine fibroblasts results in an IL-2R with intermediate affinity for IL-2. This binding is abolished by an anti-IL2R beta specific antibody,. Co-expression of IL-2 alpha, beta and gamma chains results in a high affinity IL-2 receptor. 

Patients with IL-2RB deficiency show lack of responsiveness to IL-2 despite high circulating levels and reduced signalling through IL-2 receptor.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cloning of the gamma chain of human IL-2 receptor

evidence.dc:description:
IL-15 binding was assessed using radiolabelled IL-15. High affinity IL-15 binding was demonstrated by many cell lines including human T-cells, NK-cells, monocytes and endothelial cells.

IL-15 binding is abolished by anti-IL-2RB antibodies, demonstrating that IL-2RB is a component of the IL-15 receptor. Anti-IL-2RB antibodies also abolish IL-15 induced proliferation of human PBMCs.

Decreased STAT5 signalling in response to IL-15 stimulation has been demonstrated elsewhere in patients with hypomorphic IL2RB variants.
evidence.rdfs:label: IL-2RB binds to IL-15

evidence.dc:description:
Multiple studies showing that IL-2RB is expressed on NK cells, resting T-cells, monocytes and neutrophils

On T-cells, IL-2RB expression is increased by TCR stimulation, PMA, IL-2 and IL-4
evidence.rdfs:label: IL2RB expression
